body: THEY'LL be home for Christmas: the New Church in Murray Hill, back to a lovely antebellum sanctuary it had to close in 1990; the Salvation Army, in its own Times Square building after a 12-year absence; the Brooklyn Tabernacle, in a vast old movie palace that hasn't looked so splendid since it opened in 1918; and All Saints Episcopal Church, in a
title: For Churches, Births and Rebirths

author: E-mail: eating@nytimes.com
body: Hot chocolate -- the perfect accompaniment for ice skates and shopping bags --is showing up on menus all over town. BLUE FIN ** [Rating: Two Stars] (212) 918-1400; 1567 Broadway (47th Street); $$$; Review: 3/6/02. Some of the freshest fish in town is on the menu at Blue Fin, where the oysters almost twinkle. A pot of creamy Valrhona hot chocolate
title: GOOD EATINGS; Warm-Up in a Mug

body: In a cramped fourth-floor walk-up in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a roomful of young comics crack one another up. They're not telling jokes, however. They're pitching ideas for Jest, a monthly humor magazine whose first issue appeared this month. They wonder: How about a ''Pigeon in the Street'' piece asking that perennial New York question, ''Where are
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Remember, This Is How The New Yorker Started

body: ON Jan. 23, 2001, seven actors in black coats, breeches, buckled shoes and white stockings assembled around a table at StudioEIS in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn to recreate a seminal moment in American history -- the signing of the Constitution in Philadelphia on Sept. 17, 1787 -- for photographs and eventually bronze statues. ''It was very
title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; Founding Fathers, Large as Life

body: Never mind that they are a little far from the beach. The cabanas atop the Sweeney Building, a former factory in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn that is being converted to residential lofts, are being snapped up before they even go up. Three of the six ''Tar Beach Cabanas,'' as they have been billed by David C. Walentas, the project's developer, have
title: Residential Real Estate; Cabanas for Sale: No Sand, No Sea, Skyline View

body: Ah, Brooklyn Heights! With its beautiful brownstones, lush trees and breathtaking waterfront views, who would ever move away? The parents of 5-year-olds preparing to start school can answer that. Each year, some leave for neighborhoods whose public schools have a better reputation than Brooklyn Heights' elementary school, Public School 8. In recent
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; Struggling P.S. 8 Tries to Meet Neighborhood's Expectations

body: WEEKENDS aren't so quiet anymore in Dumbo, the tiny neighborhood of old red-brick buildings on the Brooklyn waterfront. On a Sunday afternoon this month, workers were trundling rugs and furniture into the new ABC Carpet & Home store, which opened last week in a former Jay Street warehouse. Down on Water Street, St. Ann's Warehouse, a former spice
title: Over the River, No Longer Fringe

body: ONE day during the sweltering heat of August, Laurie Cearley sat in the backyard of her ground-floor Williamsburg apartment, looked up at the sky and was amazed: her fig tree was heavy with ripe green fruit. ''I was so excited,'' she recalled. ''It was like a baby.'' Ms. Cearley (pronounced CUR-lee) first laid eyes on her fig tree, a gift, five
title: GOOD COMPANY; When Figs Fall in Brooklyn, It's Time to Party

body: EVERY year Jonah Zuckerman, a furniture maker in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, participates in the Art Under the Bridge festival, a weekend when artists and craftspeople open their studios to the public. His goal in the past was to spur interest in future commissions. But when the festival kicks off tomorrow, he will have a different agenda: to
title: New Moves for Nervous Merchants

body: WHEN David Graham, a 38-year-old painter, gave up a studio carved out of an old diner in Williamsburg in 1997, 6 years into a 10-year lease to spend a year in Montreal, he figured he would have little difficulty duplicating it when he returned a year later. ''There was still a lot of space available, so I didn't think it would be a big deal,'' he
title: Artists Canvassing for Space

body: Two terms in an office that controls tens of billions of dollars in spending and his status as the front-runner have given Gov. George E. Pataki an extraordinary advantage in the contest to pull in the buckets of cash needed to run a modern-day political campaign. The true test will not come until Nov. 5. But Mr. Pataki has entered the final month
title: Big Donors' Dealings With State Give Pataki Big Advantage

body: Hip Brooklyn homesteaders will now have their own ABC Home store, in a warehouse in Dumbo at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge. The facade is decorated with colorful supergraphics on 12 loading-dock doors (below). ''The furniture in the Dumbo store will be more contemporary than in our other branches,'' said Skye Kirby, vice president of ABC's
title: CURRENTS: NEW STORES; A Warehouse of Contemporary Goods Anchored at the Manhattan Bridge

body: Jacques Torres, host of the ''Watch Chocolate'' TV show on the Food Network, does not seem to have the type of job that would lead him to worry about a war in Iraq. After all, he is consumed by creating chocolates. But Mr. Torres, who owns a chocolate factory and store on Water Street in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, says the prospect of
title: Many Fear Mideast Unrest Could Force Up Oil Prices

body: Victorian Brooklyn Muddy Waters Coffee Bar, 669 Vanderbilt Avenue at Park Place, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn; (718) 707-1277. The annual Prospect Heights House Tour, featuring 19th-century houses in the Federal Revival, Queen Anne, Italianate, Eastlake and Second Empire styles, will take place on Sunday from noon to 5 p.m. Among the nine residences
title: CALENDAR

title: SPARE TIMES

Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a

body: Space may or may not be the final frontier, but for a lot of avant-garde-minded folks, it's where the action is. This is not the kind of space that the Starship Enterprise set out to explore, however. Nor is it the 60's-style, zero-degree space that Minimalism opened up. The concept has metastasized into all kinds of what the professors call
title: ART REVIEW; Space, Inside and Out, That's Filled With Ideas About . . . Space

body: MERCIFULLY, the eligibility dispute over the Little League baseball players from Harlem didn't last long. Officials satisfied themselves that all the youngsters met the standards for living within a district's boundaries and so deserved to represent Harlem in the Little League World Series. For all the hubbub, one issue not settled was where,
title: NYC; Bronx Is Up, And Harlem Is Where?

body: Dumbo Arts Center 30 Washington Street Brooklyn Through Sept. 15 This cool, funny, light-touch show, organized by Frantiska and Tim Gilman-Sevcik, brings together an international group of young Conceptual artists for whom a clever idea is at least as important as a solid object. Domesticity prevails in wall-relief images of furniture made with
title: ART IN REVIEW; 'Pass Me the Butterfly'

body: Two new works of Internet art are really out there. No, out there, in public, where anyone can see them. This seems like an aesthetic zoning violation. Internet art often explores the digital medium's uncharted regions, but it does so from within the confines of the personal-computer screen. Internet artworks are wildly conceived, not conceived for
title: ARTS ONLINE; New Public Art Uses the Internet for a Personal Touch

body: ANNE PASTERNAK, the executive director of Creative Time, is stepping gingerly in beaded flip-flops inside the roofless shell of a 19th-century tobacco warehouse on the Brooklyn waterfront. The vast structure of brick walls, with its open-air arches, looks like a Roman aqueduct, except this ruin has the Brooklyn Bridge soaring overhead. Ms.
title: PUBLIC LIVES; An Old Warehouse? To This Art Lover, It's a Canvas

body: Partying Like It's 1983 It was not your usual Hamptons party. Right there in the middle of it was an art installation that included a stuffed zebra on a leash, blindfolded women in scarlet prom dresses and a boxer in velvet briefs. Such was the entertainment offered by the avant-garde troupe known as GAle GAtes et al., which usually appears in a
title: BOLDFACE NAMES

body: When you inhabit a neighborhood, everything from the rooftop silhouettes to the cracks in the sidewalk embeds itself in your consciousness. That is why Michael Crane, president of the Dumbo Neighborhood Association, felt a jolt on the morning of May 17 when he looked out the window and saw large copper letters being removed from the blue warehouse
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; Shedding Tears for Copper Signs That Were a Link to a Borough's Past

body: Jeff McKay, a media consultant, was jogging toward ground zero three weeks ago when he started seeing ''For Rent'' signs in Battery Park City high-rise buildings. He raced home, called a real estate agent and learned that there were cheap rental deals, not just in Battery Park City but all over Manhattan. In the same call, he found out that the
title: Suddenly, People Are Thinking Rent

body: ''ASK me what I had for dinner last night,'' Lisa Versacio said. Without waiting, she shot out the answer: ''French fries and three glasses of Champagne.'' Ms. Versacio is the senior vice president of West Elm, a home furnishings company that made its debut last week when the first of 675,000 catalogs started dropping into mailboxes across the
title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK; Under-a-Thousand-Somethings for Under-40-Somethings

body: ON a recent afternoon, a pot of pink hydrangeas arrived at Metaphor Contemporary Art, a gallery on the 11th floor of a warehouse in Brooklyn near the Manhattan Bridge. Julian Jackson, 48, the gallery's boyish co-owner, gingerly carried the flowerpot through a crisp, white room that was dotted with abstract paintings. He ducked behind a curtained
title: SPACES; Gallery? Studio? Home? Blurring the Lines, Artists Paint and Sell

body: IT'S just a guess, but Tuller Premium Food, a tiny takeout shop in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, may offer the most flavor per square inch in New York. It is crammed with delicious things, including dulce de leche ice cream from Spain; dense, rustic rolls from Pain d'Avignon in Long Island City; chocolate bark from Jacques Torres's new shop in Dumbo; and,
title: TO GO; International Delicacies, by the Square Inch

body: THINK of it as a ''Follies'' for the Electronic Age. ''Xtravaganza,'' the latest multimedia piece by the experimental troupe the Builders Association, cuts up early-20th-century history of American popular entertainment and splices together a computer-aided hybrid that seeks to push theatrical presentation into new territory. Subtitled ''Ten Acts
title: THEATER; Chopping Up History to Make A New Stew

body: STAINED-GLASS windows are most often seen at a distance, in the soaring spaces of castles and cathedrals. But a full appreciation of their painted and leaded detailing is possible only up close, preferably not on a ladder but at eye level in a gallery. And this is exactly what is available in ''Masterworks in Stained Glass: Rediscovering the
title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; Stained Glass Buffed Up To Its 600-Year-Old Glory

body: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about projections of people's faces on a clock tower in Dumbo, Brooklyn, misstated the date of a radio broadcast of what they are saying. It will be on WFMU-FM (91.1) on May 3, from 8 p.m. to 9 p.m., not on May 5, which is the last night the images will appear.
title: Corrections

body: No one has ever seen a State Assembly district line drawn on the ground. And yet they can seem as real as fences. At a recent round of redistricting hearings, people from all over the state fought to move their lines, citing reasons as diverse as racial balance and the omission of a particular park or school. But the tiny neighborhood of Vinegar
title: Enclave Links Its Political Fate to Its Rich History

body: For the next month, passers-by at night may notice something odd about the Clock Tower building in Dumbo: people on the clocks. Some will look small and far away. Others will loom so large that a single eyeball will span the 14-foot clock face. A young boy will ride a hobby horse across one clock. The people will speak, too, though for the most
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; Enigmatic Images On a Clock Tower, Offering A New York State of Mind

body: A high point of the current Whitney Biennial is its lively film and video program. Organized by the curator Chrissie Iles, it accounts for nearly half of the show, and one of its artists, the filmmaker Irit Batsry, has received this year's Bucksbaum award. As it happens, film and video are also plentiful in New York galleries these days. The
title: ART REVIEW; Cinema à la Warhol, With Cowboys, Stillness and Glamour

body: A mixed-use development for downtown Brooklyn on city-owned land near the Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill Historic Districts has been approved by the New York City Economic Development Corporation. Two Trees Management, known for its activity in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn near the Manhattan Bridge, has been chosen to develop about 500,000
title: POSTINGS: Mixed-Use Project on Atlantic Avenue; $90 Million Plan For Brooklyn

body: FINDING that just-right combination of affordable and suitable artists' space in Westchester can be a formidable undertaking. Many low-priced rentals are in dilapidated buildings in run-down areas. Many are too far away from the artists' markets in Manhattan. And when an artist finally discovers space that fits the bill, there is always the worry
title: In the Region/Westchester; Helping Artists Find Affordable and Suitable Space

title: SPARE TIMES

body: The story is almost believable. In 1899, a collection of ancient Greek pottery shards was shipped from an excavation site in Italy to a Brooklyn cultural institution. Through some mix-up, or possibly through devious machinations, the crate arriving at the institution contained grapefruit. The shards are believed to have landed in the area of the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; A Search for Shards That Is Not What It Seems

body: PEDRO PEREZ has a wife whose name is Carmen and a son whose name is Pedrito (Little Pedro). He keeps them above his restaurant, which is called Pedro's Spanish American Restaurant, in Brooklyn under the Manhattan Bridge. Mr. Perez has been in this spot for a long time. Since before the real estate agents called it Dumbo. Way before the refugees
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENDING ELBOWS; Before There Was Dumbo, There Was Pedro's

body: For the full impact of a certain Russian experience, nothing quite beats ''War and Peace.'' The book is long, and so is the opera. It has falling snow and ballroom dancing, soul-searching and vodka bingeing, honor and dishonor, not to mention the main themes, which are, of course, war and peace. (''Some subject, eh?'' as an American tourist said
title: A Little Russia On the Hudson

body: JAGON ELDRIDGE, a saxophonist, was spending $550 a month for a 6-by-6-foot cubicle with paper-thin walls on the Upper West Side, his ears assaulted by unruly children next door. Kate Wattson, a painter, was negotiating the end of her marriage from a sun-deprived garden apartment in Brooklyn Heights. John Pavlou, a sculptor, was living over his
title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK; Grooming a Little Montmartre, Just North of the Bronx

body: FOR more than 20 years, the Wooster Group, the downtown avant-garde theater troupe, has been presenting its unique theatrical experiments in a drafty former flatware factory in SoHo known as the Performing Garage. And while the Garage has been home to some of the group's best-known work (including ''Brace Up!'' in 1991 and ''House/ Lights'' in
title: Spring Theater; Pulling Out of the Garage for a Visit to Brooklyn

body: Arts at St. Ann's, a performing arts center that started at St. Ann's Church in Brooklyn Heights and moved into a new home in October, has raised the curtain on its first continuous theatrical run since its inception 22 years ago. The play stars Frances McDormand and Willem Dafoe. ''To You, the Birdie! (Phèdre),'' an adaptation of the Racine play
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DUMBO; St. Ann's Arts Group Inaugurates Longest Run

body: AS construction work begins on 9 MetroTech South, a 670,000-square-foot building that will house 1,300 employees of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, planning is under way to lay the zoning and other groundwork for other development in downtown Brooklyn. While the new building will complete development of the 16-acre MetroTech complex, its
title: In Brooklyn, Projects, Plans and Hopes
